results.title: The Aviators of Hudson Strait
results.creator_credit: William Weintraub and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A look at early Canadian aviation, through film footage shot by the Royal Canadian Air Force and the recollections of retired Air Vice-Marshal Thomas A. Lawrence, leader of the 1927-28 aerial survey expedition to Ungava Bay and Hudson Strait. The formidable challenge of flying under Arctic conditions, the hazards faced and the emergencies solved, often with the help of Inuit, make an absorbing chapter of northern frontier history. Written by William Weintraub.
results.creator_credit_for_label: William Weintraub and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: The Backbone of life
results.creator_credit: John Gauci, Gus Mercurio and Gus Mercurio Enterprises
results.brief_description: Gus Mercurio has been a Registered Doctor of Chiropractic for over 35 years. These routines have enriched his own life and can do the same for you. The whole routine in 2 parts takes less than 40 minutes to complete and can be easily adapted to your day. Designed for the mature, it includes stretching and toning, low impact aerobics - walking, swimming or cycling - weight training and isometrics and relaxation. Proper sleep support and dietary advice are covered to make this tape a must for any-one suffering muscular or back discomfort.

results.title: South West Tasmania: The Gliders (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Catherine Millar, John Richardson and Kestrel Film Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Australian wilderness series”.
The sheer challenge of remote wilderness is shown in this spectacular program of a group’s arduous trek up Federation Peak with the aim of hang gliding from the top. Young and old take part in the trek and viewers share in the thoughts, inspiration and differing goals of the group.

results.title: Kimberley: Wandjina country
results.creator_credit: David Morgan, John Richardson and Kestrel Film Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Australian wilderness series”.
Part three of a series of six documentaries that examine the wilderness areas of Australia. Belinda Wright and Stanley Breeden are naturalists and photographers who work for the National Geographic Society. As they become fascinated with the “Wandjina” rock paintings, the viewer also gains some insight into the deep, spiritual relationship the Aboriginal people have with the land. A Teacher’s guide accompanies the video.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David Morgan, John Richardson and Kestrel Film Productions

results.title: Kakadu: Land of the Crocodile
results.creator_credit: David Greig, John Richardson and Kestrel Films (Australia)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Australian wilderness series”.
Wilderness is increasingly recognised as a scarce and vital commodity worldwide. In this video, Part 2 in a series of 6 documentaries, Val Plumwood, environmental philosopher and writer returns to Kakadu, where she was the victim of a terrible crocodile attack. Set against the steamy, intensely beautiful, backdrop of Kakadu National Park viewers share her thoughts on wilderness and wildlife. Accompanied by a Teacher’s Guide.

results.title: Indelible impressions
results.brief_description: A family of women – they share pride and a passion for life; a love for dancing, talking and eating and each woman has left an indelible impression on those of the next generation. In this story Jade shares her memories and thoughts with the newest and youngest member in the family, her niece, and poses the question, “Will the women of our family leave an indelible mark on you just as they did on me?”

results.title: Just like dad
results.brief_description: Gemma’s dad, an old rocker from way back, is passionate about music and anything and everything that is remotely connected to music. This addiction comes to a head when dad discovers Ebay on the home computer. Searches and purchases; Ebay has taken over his life. Worse still, Ebay the enemy is now growing on Gemma. She is her father’s daughter! Uses stills and animation.

results.title: My Nana
results.brief_description: This is a loving tribute to Lorna Joyce Harrington by her grand-daughter, Rebecca. Born into a family of boys in Nunga, Northern Victoria in 1924, Lorna Harrington was separated from her family at the age of 3 weeks old until 7 years old when her mother was too sick to look after her. She worked on the family farm from the age of 13 after her father passed away, eventually escaping to Shepparton to work in the cannery and then finally marrying and settling in Melbourne. To Rebecca, “nana” is the rock in her family - a caring, strong and independent person who has taught her so many things in life.

results.title: Central Australia: tracks in the sand
results.creator_credit: John Richardson and Kestrel Film Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Australian wilderness series”.
Cartoonist Michael Leunig records his impressions of Alice Springs, Ayers Rock and the vast emptiness of the Simpson Desert. Viewers are privy to a special meeting of minds and cultures, when he shares a canvas on the sand with Aboriginal artist, Michael Nelson. Accompanied by a Teacher’s guide.

Cartoonist Michael Leunig records his impressions of Alice Springs, Ayers Rock and the vast emptiness of the Simpson Desert. Viewers are privy to a special meeting of minds and cultures, when he shares a canvas on the sand with Aboriginal artist, Michael Nelson. Accompanied by a Teacher’s guide.
